parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviours in rhesus macaques.
[Statement 2]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased foraging and activity levels in gorillas.
[Statement 3]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced abnormal behaviours in chimpanzees.
[Statement 4]: Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced aggression in lemurs.
[Statement 5]: Hiding food in containers, such as boxes, baskets or tubes, with the addition of browse, led to increased activity levels and foraging behaviours in lemurs and gibbons.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do the effects of scattering food throughout a primate's enclosure compare with hiding it in containers?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in Germany and Austria found that simulating a wet and dry season stimulated breeding and egg deposition.
[Statement 2]: One before-and-after study in Austria found that captive frogs started breeding when housed in enclosures with more calling, perching and laying sites.
[Statement 3]: One before-and-after study in Austria found that captive frogs started breeding when housed in enclosures with simulated wet and dry seasons.
[Statement 4]: One replicated study in Fiji found that adding rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes to an enclosure promoted egg laying in frogs.
[Statement 5]: A replicated, before-and-after study in Australia found that the clutch size of frogs increased when females had mate choice.
[Statement 6]: A replicated, before-and-after study in Australia found that the clutch size of frogs increased when females were exposed to recorded mating calls.
[Statement 7]: A replicated, before-and-after study in Australia found that the clutch size of frogs increased when the sexes were separated during non-breeding periods.
[Statement 8]: No evidence was captured for the effects of allowing temperate amphibians to hibernate.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What evidence exists for stimulating breeding in captive amphibians by manipulating environmental cues like temperature, rainfall, and sound?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Feeding whole carcasses to lions, leopards, snow leopards, and cougars in zoos reduced pacing levels.
[Statement 2]: A feeding regimen of whole carcasses led to an increase in pacing for tigers.
[Statement 3]: In cheetahs, a diet of whole rabbit resulted in lower blood protein urea, zinc, and vitamin A levels compared to supplemented beef.
[Statement 4]: A diet of whole rabbit for cheetahs showed lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators.
[Statement 5]: Ocelots fed whole chickens exhibited lower digestible energy and fat compared to a commercial diet.
[Statement 6]: For African wildcats, a whole chicken diet resulted in lower organic matter digestibility compared to a ground-chicken diet.
[Statement 7]: Providing bones to large felids, such as lions and tigers, decreased the frequency of stereotypic behaviors.
[Statement 8]: Providing bones to large felids, such as lions and tigers, increased activity and manipulation time.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated, controlled study in the USA found that when chimpanzees were fed on unpredictable schedules, the chimpanzees' inactivity decreased.
[Statement 2]: A replicated, controlled study in the USA reported that an enrichment task took less time to complete when monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone.
[Statement 3]: A before-and-after study in Italy found that in the presence of the monkeys' groupmates, monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter.
[Statement 4]: No evidence was captured for the effects of providing primates access to food at all times (day and night).

parts.text:

[Statement 2]: A decrease in stereotypical pacing was found in leopard cats and black bears after hiding food.
[Statement 3]: Hiding food reduced the time Canadian lynx spent sleeping during the day.
[Statement 4]: Scattered feeding increased locomotion in maned wolves.
[Statement 5]: Maned wolves spent more time in the section of an enclosure with scattered food than in a section with food on a tray.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the UK found that when captive loris were provided with live insect prey, the loris' inactivity was reduced to levels seen in wild loris.
[Statement 2]: A study in the UK found that when captive loris were provided with live insect prey, the loris' foraging increased to levels seen in wild loris.
[Statement 3]: Three studies evaluated the effects of providing live natural prey to captive mammals to foster hunting behaviour before release.
[Statement 4]: Two studies in Spain and Botswana found that a rehabilitated Iberian lynx that was provided with live natural prey in captivity survived for between at least three months and 19 months after release.
[Statement 5]: Two studies in Spain and Botswana found that wild-born but captive-reared orphaned cheetahs and leopards that were provided with live natural prey in captivity survived for between at least three months and 19 months after release.
[Statement 6]: A controlled study in the USA found that captive-bred black-footed ferrets fed on live prairie dogs took longer to disperse after release than did ferrets not fed with live prairie dogs.
[Statement 7]: A controlled study in the USA found that captive-bred black-footed ferrets fed on live prairie dogs showed greater subsequent movements than did ferrets not fed with live prairie dogs.
[Statement 8]: A study in the USA found that hunting behaviour increased in a fishing cat when the fishing cat was provided with live fish.
[Statement 9]: A study in the USA found that sleeping decreased in a fishing cat when the fishing cat was provided with live fish.
[Statement 10]: A replicated study in the USA found that there was no change in the occurrence of stereotypical behaviours in tigers when the tigers were provided with live fish.

[Statement 1]: Tadpoles fed a control diet of rabbit chow and fish food or freshwater algae had higher body mass and reached a more advanced developmental stage compared to tadpoles fed only pine or oak pollen.
[Statement 2]: Tadpoles fed only pollen did not undergo metamorphosis.
[Statement 3]: Tadpoles reared on a diet with 46% protein had higher growth rates, survival, and body weights at metamorphosis compared to tadpoles on diets with less protein.
[Statement 4]: Egg production for salamanders in captivity has been successful.
[Statement 5]: Semi-natural tank habitats were more successful for salamander egg production than laboratory conditions.
[Statement 6]: Larval development, body condition, and survival of captive-bred amphibians were influenced by water temperature and density.
[Statement 7]: There was no evidence found for the effects of supplementing diets with vitamins or calcium through dusting prey.
[Statement 8]: There was no evidence found for the effects of supplementing diets with vitamins or calcium through gut-loading prey.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: For maned wolves, a plant-derived protein diet increased digestible energy and dry matter digestibility when compared to an animal-based protein diet.
[Statement 2]: For maned wolves, a plant-derived protein diet decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine levels when compared to an animal-based protein diet.
[Statement 3]: Supplementing an animal-protein diet with taurine increased plasma taurine levels in maned wolves.
[Statement 4]: When provided a commercial diet, maned wolves had similar dry matter intake and digestibility despite a lower protein content in the diet.
[Statement 5]: For cheetahs, a commercial diet resulted in a similar likelihood of developing gastritis as cheetahs fed horse meat.
[Statement 6]: A commercial diet for cheetahs resulted in lower levels of blood protein urea and higher levels of creatine when compared to a diet of horse meat.
[Statement 7]: For cheetahs, a commercial meat diet resulted in plasma a-tocopherol, retinol and taurine concentrations within the ranges recommended for domestic cats.
[Statement 8]: For cheetahs, a diet of whole chicken carcasses resulted in plasma a-tocopherol, retinol and taurine concentrations within the ranges recommended for domestic cats.
[Statement 9]: For leopards, providing Jerusalem artichoke as a supplement increased two types of gut microbiota, faecal scores and faecal moisture content.
[Statement 10]: No evidence was found for the effect of supplementing meat-based diets with vitamins on captive carnivores.
[Statement 11]: No evidence was found for the effect of supplementing meat-based diets with minerals on captive carnivores.
[Statement 12]: No evidence was found for the effect of supplementing meat-based diets with fatty acids on captive carnivores.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Providing live prey to captive primates and carnivores has yielded a range of behavioral outcomes.
[Statement 2]: Providing live insect prey to captive loris led to a reduction in inactivity.

[Statement 9]: Black-footed ferrets that were fed live prairie dogs demonstrated greater subsequent movements after being released.
[Statement 10]: A rehabilitated Iberian lynx and orphaned cheetahs and leopards that had been provided with live natural prey in captivity were found to have survived for a minimum of three to nineteen months after release.

[Statement 7]: Other studies found that hormone treatment for female amphibians did not stimulate egg production or successful breeding.
[Statement 8]: In addition to hormone treatment, environmental manipulations have also been found to be effective in captive breeding programs for frogs.
[Statement 9]: The reproductive success of frogs in captivity has been found to depend on temperature.
[Statement 10]: The reproductive success of frogs in captivity has been found to depend on a simulated wet and dry season.
[Statement 11]: Providing a variety of substrates has been shown to promote egg-laying in frogs.
[Statement 12]: Providing substrates such as rotting logs has been shown to promote egg-laying in frogs.
[Statement 13]: Providing substrates such as hollow bamboo pipes has been shown to promote egg-laying in frogs.
[Statement 14]: Temporarily flooding enclosures was found to be a successful intervention for breeding Australian frogs.

[Statement 16]: Playing recorded mating calls was found to be a successful intervention for breeding Australian frogs.
